SENT.plain: This study was done to evaluate the frequency, intensity, and specificity of a positive pathergy reaction (PR) in Behcet's disease (BD) patients, to clarify an association between the PR and the clinical features or disease severity, and to assess whether patients with pustule formation at the venous puncture site (PFVPS) without positive PR could be regarded as a positive reaction
The PR was tested in 64 BD patients, 74 disease controls, and 20 healthy controls
Venous PR was performed in 8 BD patients with PFVPS
Follow-up PR was done in 14 patients with positive reaction during inactive phase
The PR was positive in 35.9% of BD patients, in 1 patient among disease controls, and in none of healthy controls
The pustule formation was observed in one BD patient
There was no statistical significance between positive PR and the clinical variables
The mean clinical activity score of BD patients with positive PR was similar to patients with negative reaction
Venous PR was positive in 7 patients
The follow-up PR was positive in 2 patients during inactive phase

Conclusively the positive PR appeared to be specific for BD, and was not associated with the clinical variables or disease severity, but was usually found during active phase in cases with positive reaction
The PFVPS in patients with negative PR might be considered to be positive
